clinical_study.brief_title: Traumatized Refugees -Stress Management Versus Cognitive Re-structuring
clinical_study.official_title: Treatment With Cognitive Behavioural Therapy in Traumatised Refugees - Stress Management Versus Cognitive Restructuring - a Randomised Clinical Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Mental Health Services in the Capital Region, Denmark

clinical_study.source: Mental Health Services in the Capital Region, Denmark

brief_summary.textblock: The Competence Centre for Transcultural Psychiatry is a clinic specialised in the treatment of traumatised refugees. There is a lack of studies on treatment effect in traumatised refugees. There are several studies indicating an effect of cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) in Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). A few studies point to that CBT could be effective in traumatised refugees. There are no studies examining if some methods used in CBT are more useful than others in traumatised refugees. The aim of this study is to examine the effect of CBT with focus on Stress Management versus cognitive restructuring. Patients included in this study will be randomised to either Stress Management or cognitive restructuring. All referred patients will receive medical treatment as usual (described in the clinic's manual for medical doctors, 2011). All patients that fulfill the inclusion criteria will be included in the study. Hopefully this study will contribute to improve the psychotherapeutic treatment offered to traumatised refugees.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in PTSD symptoms measured by the first 16 items in the Harvard Trauma Questionnaire (HTQ)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, after 2 months and after 6 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in depressive symptoms measured by the Hopkins Symptoms Checklist-25 (HSCL-25), depressive items
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, after 2 months and after 6 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in anxiety symptoms measured by the Hopkins Symptom Checklist-25 (HSCL-25), anxiety items
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, after 2 months and after 6 months

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in quality of life measured by the WHO-5
Changes in functioning measured by the the Sheehan Disability Scale (SDS)
Achievement of goals set at beginning of psychotherapy using Goal Attainment Scaling (GAS)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Refugee or patient that has been reunified with family member being a refugee.
- Symptoms of PTSD in accordance with International Classification of Diseases-10 (ICD-10) research criteria.
- Trauma in the past such as imprisonment, torture (according to UN definition), war experiences.
- Referred by a medical doctor.
- Motivated for treatment.
- Informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe psychotic illness such as schizophrenia or bipolar disorder
- Drug abuse
- Patients admitted to in ward treatment
- No informed consent
